required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Natural Killer (NK) Cell Transplantation for AML
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study Of Haplo-Identical Natural Killer Cell Transplantation For Acute Myeloid Leukemia

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the safety and efficacy of infusing natural killer cells from a donor as treatment for patients with acute myeloid leukemia in remission or who have experienced relapse.

detailed_description.textblock:
Natural killer (NK) cells extracted from a [parental] donor are infused intravenously. Most patients are given a multi-agent chemotherapeutic conditioning regimen prior to the infusion. The conditioning regimen may be omitted for patients who have previously received traditional stem cell transplant.
Details of Treatment Plan:
Stratum 1 (AML in complete remission)
Cyclophosphamide 60 mg/kg IV Day -7 Fludarabine 25 mg/m2/day IV Days -6 through -2 Donor pheresis Day -1 Start IL-2 on Day -1, then 3 times per week x 2 weeks NK Cell purification and infusion on Day 0
Stratum 2 (AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease)
Clofarabine 40 mg/m2 IV, days -6 through -2 Etoposide 100 mg/m2 IV, days -6 through -2 Cyclophosphamide 400 mg/m2 IV, days -6 through 02 Donor pheresis Day -1 Start IL-2 Day -1, and then 3 times per week x 2 weeks NK Cell purification and infusion on Day 0.
For patients who have received prior SCT, the conditioning regimen may be omitted if the NK cells are obtained from the original SCT donor.
Cytokine regimen (stratum 1 and 2): 1 million units/m2 of IL-2 given subcutaneously three times per week for two weeks (6 doses) starting on the evening of day -1.
NK Cell Transplantation (stratum 1 and 2): NK cells from haplo-identical family donor will be infused on day 0.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients Experiencing Grade 3 or 4 Toxicities During Conditioning and up to 100 Days Post-transplant
primary_outcome.time_frame: Beginning at on therapy through 100 days post-transplant
primary_outcome.description: Document the number of patients experiencing grade 3 or 4 toxicities during conditioning and up to 100 days post-transplant. Toxicities were identified using Common Toxicity Criteria V 3.0 criteria.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Patients Experiencing Grade 3 or 4 Toxicities During Conditioning and up to 100 Days Post-transplant
primary_outcome.time_frame: Beginning at on therapy through 100 days post-transplant
primary_outcome.description: Document the proportion of patients experiencing grade 3 or 4 toxicities during conditioning and up to 100 days post-transplant. Toxicities were identified using Common Toxicity Criteria V 3.0 criteria.

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of Engraftment of Natural Killer (NK) Cells
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at days 2, 7, 14, 21 and 28 after NK cell transplantation, and up to 189 days post transplant as clinically indicated
secondary_outcome.description: NK cell engraftment defined as NK cell chimerism in recipients.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent of Peak NK Cell Chimerism
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 2, 7, 14, 21 and 28 after NK cell transplantation
secondary_outcome.description: The maximum percent of donor NK cell in recipients during a four-week period after NK cell infusion.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent of Detectable Donor NK Cells at Day 28
secondary_outcome.description: The percent of detectable donor NK cells in recipients at 28 days after NK cell infusion. Three of 10 participants had detectable donor cells at week 4. The results report the percent of detectable cells in the 3 participants.

secondary_outcome.measure: Day That Maximum NK Cell Engraftment Was Reached
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 0 through Day 28 post NK cell transplantation
secondary_outcome.description: The time elapsed after transplantation in days until peak KIR-mismatched donor NK cell expansion was reached in recipients

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 2 and day 14 post NK cell transplantation
secondary_outcome.description: Number of KIR-mismatched donor NK cells in recipients' blood at day 2 and day 14 post NK cell infusion.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Evidence of NK Cells Lysing a Target Cell Line (K562)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 2, 7, 14, 21, and 28 after NK cell transplantation
secondary_outcome.description: NK cells in recipient achieving ability to lyse target cell line (K562) within normal range established by donor NK cells.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 2 years post NK cell transplantation
secondary_outcome.description: For Arm 1, the efficacy of NK cell transplantation will be reported as the proportion of participants who achieve complete or partial remission. Kaplan-Meier estimates of relapse-free survival and confidence interval was determined by binomial distribution because no events were observed. The binomial interval is based on the number of patients at risk.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 2 years post NK cell transplantation
secondary_outcome.description: Overall survival is defined as the time relapse from on study date to death with those alive at last follow up date censored. The Kaplan-Meier method was used to compute survival probability estimates and confidence interval was determined by binomial distribution (for no events or all events) or by log hazard method. The binomial interval is based on the number of patients at risk. The confidence intervals for Arm 1 and Arm 2a were determined by binomial distribution. The confidence interval for Arm 2b was determined by log hazard method.

arm_group.description: Stratum 1 (AML in complete remission) Cyclophosphamide 60 mg/kg IV Day -7 Fludarabine 25 mg/m2/day IV Days -6 through -2 Donor pheresis Day -1 Start IL-2 on Day -1, then 3 times per week x 2 weeks NK Cell purification and infusion on Day 0

Stratum 2 (AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease) Clofarabine 40 mg/m2 IV, days -6 through -2 Etoposide 100 mg/m2 IV, days -6 through -2 Cyclophosphamide 400 mg/m2 IV, days -6 through 02 Donor pheresis Day -1 Start IL-2 Day -1, and then 3 times per week x 2 weeks NK Cell purification and infusion on Day 0.

intervention.description: See Detailed Description section for additional details of treatment interventions.
See Detailed Description section for additional details of treatment interventions.
See Detailed Description section for additional details of treatment interventions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participants with AML that is in complete remission, is relapsed or refractory, or with increasing minimal residual disease.
- Participants in complete remission must have recovered from toxicity of previous therapy and have evidence of bone marrow recovery
- Participants who had prior stem cell transplant (SCT) must have no evidence of GVHD and 60 or more days have elapsed since the SCT.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participants who are pregnant
- Participants with inadequate renal, liver, or pulmonary functions

results_reference.citation: Rubnitz JE, Inaba H, Ribeiro RC, Pounds S, Rooney B, Bell T, Pui CH, Leung W. NKAML: a pilot study to determine the safety and feasibility of haploidentical natural killer cell transplantation in childhood acute myeloid leukemia. J Clin Oncol. 2010 Feb 20;28(6):955-9. doi: 10.1200/JCO.2009.24.4590. Epub 2010 Jan 19.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: 49 participants were recruited between October 2005 and October 2011.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 49 participants were enrolled on the study. This report is based on results for 25 patients. 24 were donors and were excluded. All analyses are based on the intent-to-treat principle and therefore include all recipients with data available for the reported endpoint.

group.title: Arm 1: Conditioning Regimen: Cyclophosphamide/Fludarabine
group.description: Participants with AML in complete remission (stratum 1). AML in complete remission is defined as trilineage hematopoietic recovery with less than 5% blasts in the marrow. Arm 1 participants received a traditional conditioning regimen of cyclophosphamide and fludarabine prior to NK cell transplantation.

group.title: Arm 2a: Conditioning Regimen: Cyclophosphamide/Fludarabine
group.description: AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease (MRD) (stratum 2). Participants enrolled prior to Amendment 2.0 received a traditional conditioning regimen of cyclophosphamide and fludarabine prior to NK cell transplantation.

group.title: Arm 2b: Conditioning: Clofarabine/Etoposide/Cyclophosphamide
group.description: AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease (MRD) (stratum 2). Participants enrolled after protocol Amendment 2.0 received a novel conditioning regimen of clofarabine, etoposide and cyclophosphamide prior to NK cell transplantation.

group.title: Arm 1: Conditioning Regimen: Cyclophosphamide/Fludarabine
group.description: AML in complete remission (stratum 1). AML in complete remission is defined as trilineage hematopoietic recovery with less than 5% blasts in the marrow. Arm 1 participants received a traditional conditioning regimen of cyclophosphamide and fludarabine prior to NK cell transplantation.

group.title: Arm 2a: Conditioning Regimen: Cyclophosphamide/Fludarabine
group.description: AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease (MRD) (stratum 2). Participants enrolled prior to Amendment 2.0 received a traditional conditioning regimen of cyclophosphamide and fludarabine prior to NK cell transplantation.

group.title: Arm 2b: Conditioning: Clofarabine/Etoposide/Cyclophosphamide
group.description: AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease (MRD) (stratum 2). Participants enrolled after protocol Amendment 2.0 received a novel conditioning regimen of clofarabine, etoposide and cyclophosphamide prior to NK cell transplantation.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Number of Patients Experiencing Grade 3 or 4 Toxicities During Conditioning and up to 100 Days Post-transplant
outcome.description: Document the number of patients experiencing grade 3 or 4 toxicities during conditioning and up to 100 days post-transplant. Toxicities were identified using Common Toxicity Criteria V 3.0 criteria.
outcome.time_frame: Beginning at on therapy through 100 days post-transplant
outcome.population: Grade 3 and 4 toxicities were assessed using Common Toxicity Criteria V.3.0 The assessment period was from the date on therapy through 100 days post-transplant.

group.title: Arm 1: Conditioning Regimen: Cyclophosphamide/Fludarabine
group.description: AML in complete remission (stratum 1). AML in complete remission is defined as trilineage hematopoietic recovery with less than 5% blasts in the marrow. Participants received a traditional conditioning regimen of cyclophosphamide and fludarabine prior to NK cell transplantation.

group.title: Arm 2a: Conditioning Regimen: Cyclophosphamide/Fludarabine
group.description: AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease (MRD). Participants enrolled prior to Amendment 2.0 received a traditional conditioning regimen of cyclophosphamide and fludarabine prior to NK cell transplantation. Refractory: ≥ 20% leukemic blasts in the bone marrow or no decrease in the percentage of blasts in the bone marrow (e.g., if a patient starts with 15% blasts and still has 15% blasts, he would have refractory disease). Relapse: presence of ≥ 20% leukemic blasts in the bone marrow or the development of extramedullary disease after CR is achieved. Increasing Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) indicates higher MRD levels.

group.title: Arm 2b: Conditioning: Clofarabine/Etoposide/Cyclophosphamide
group.description: AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease (MRD) (stratum 2). Participants enrolled after protocol Amendment 2 received a novel conditioning regimen of clofarabine, etoposide and cyclophosphamide prior to NK cell transplantation.

measure.population: Grade 3 and 4 toxicities were assessed using Common Toxicity Criteria V.3.0 The assessment period was from the date on therapy through 100 days post-transplant.

Refractory: ≥ 20% leukemic blasts in the bone marrow or no decrease in the percentage of blasts in the bone marrow (e.g., if a patient starts with 15% blasts and still has 15% blasts, he would have refractory disease). Relapse: presence of ≥ 20% leukemic blasts in the bone marrow or the development of extramedullary disease after CR is achieved. Increasing Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) indicates higher MRD levels.

outcome.population: Arm 2 participants were not analyzed for this outcome as many of these patients proceeded to allogeneic stem cell transplantation following NK cell transplantation.

outcome.description: The percent of detectable donor NK cells in recipients at 28 days after NK cell infusion. Three of 10 participants had detectable donor cells at week 4. The results report the percent of detectable cells in the 3 participants.
outcome.population: Three of 10 participants continued to have detectable donor NK cells at week 4.

outcome.title: Day That Maximum NK Cell Engraftment Was Reached
outcome.description: The time elapsed after transplantation in days until peak KIR-mismatched donor NK cell expansion was reached in recipients
outcome.time_frame: Day 0 through Day 28 post NK cell transplantation
outcome.population: Nine of the 10 participants in Arm 1 received KIR-mismatched NK donor cells.

class.title: Did not Lyse within normal range

outcome.title: Relapse-free Survival
outcome.description: For Arm 1, the efficacy of NK cell transplantation will be reported as the proportion of participants who achieve complete or partial remission. Kaplan-Meier estimates of relapse-free survival and confidence interval was determined by binomial distribution because no events were observed. The binomial interval is based on the number of patients at risk.
outcome.time_frame: Up to 2 years post NK cell transplantation

Relapse: presence of ≥ 20% leukemic blasts in the bone marrow or the development of extramedullary disease after CR is achieved. measure.title: Relapse-free Survival
measure.description: For Arm 1, the efficacy of NK cell transplantation will be reported as the proportion of participants who achieve complete or partial remission. Kaplan-Meier estimates of relapse-free survival and confidence interval was determined by binomial distribution because no events were observed. The binomial interval is based on the number of patients at risk.

outcome.title: Overall Survival
outcome.description: Overall survival is defined as the time relapse from on study date to death with those alive at last follow up date censored. The Kaplan-Meier method was used to compute survival probability estimates and confidence interval was determined by binomial distribution (for no events or all events) or by log hazard method. The binomial interval is based on the number of patients at risk. The confidence intervals for Arm 1 and Arm 2a were determined by binomial distribution. The confidence interval for Arm 2b was determined by log hazard method.
outcome.time_frame: Up to 2 years post NK cell transplantation

measure.description: Overall survival is defined as the time relapse from on study date to death with those alive at last follow up date censored. The Kaplan-Meier method was used to compute survival probability estimates and confidence interval was determined by binomial distribution (for no events or all events) or by log hazard method. The binomial interval is based on the number of patients at risk. The confidence intervals for Arm 1 and Arm 2a were determined by binomial distribution. The confidence interval for Arm 2b was determined by log hazard method.

reported_events.time_frame: Beginning at on therapy through 100 days post-transplant

group.title: Arm 2a: Conditioning Regimen: Cyclophosphamide/Fludarabine
group.description: AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease (MRD). Participants enrolled prior to Amendment 2.0 received a traditional conditioning regimen of cyclophosphamide and fludarabine prior to NK cell transplantation. Refractory: ≥ 20% leukemic blasts in the bone marrow or no decrease in the percentage of blasts in the bone marrow (e.g., if a patient starts with 15% blasts and still has 15% blasts, he would have refractory disease). Relapse: presence of ≥ 20% leukemic blasts in the bone marrow or the development of extramedullary disease after CR is achieved. Increasing Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) indicates higher MRD levels.

group.title: Arm 2b: Conditioning: Clofarabine/Etoposide/Cyclophosphamide
group.description: AML that is refractory or relapsed or AML with increasing minimal residual disease (MRD) (stratum 2). Participants enrolled after protocol Amendment 2 received a novel conditioning regimen of clofarabine, etoposide and cyclophosphamide prior to NK cell transplantation.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
